moves.1. d4 d5 2. Bf4 Nc6 3. Nf3 Nf6 4. e3 Nh5: Here, after this weak black move, the firework start.
moves.8. Ng5: Not only the knight is untakable, but it frees the way to the queen.
moves.8... Nb4: Black chooses to remove the bishop, but it is very slow.
moves.9. Qf3: The only alternate move for black is Be6, accepting the consecuences. Black choosed...
moves.9... Nxd3+ 10. cxd3: Black has the same problem right now.
moves.11. Qh5+ Kd7: Now, I looked and looked and I didn't see anything better than to win a rook. I feared I could have thrown it away and lose the knight.
moves.12. Nf7 Qe8 13. Nxh8 Qxh5 14. Rxh5: I won a rook, and black's is very, very cramped. Still, I have to fight.
moves.16. Ng6 Bd6: Here, I sensed that probably it was possible to get more from the position that a choking endgame.
moves.17. dxc5 Bxc5 18. Nxd5: With a bishop pair against a knight's one, when the pawns become to be exchanged, my opponent would improve his position. I have a rook, true, so why don't get some emotion in it?
moves.18... exd5 19. Rxd5+: This leaves the king a single square.
moves.19... Kc6 20. Rd8: e4 was the alternate move. Not Nf4, g5.
moves.20... Kc7 21. Rg8: Black can't defend the pawn. But he had a good idea...
moves.21... Bb4+ 22. Ke2: ?? Kf1 was the simple move to victory. I simply overlooked the following, natural...
moves.25. Rc1+ Kd6 26. a3 Ba5 27. d4: It is not necessary to help my opponent to have the pieces in its natural square (b6).
moves.27... Re8 28. Kd3 b5: This actually half-helps me opening squares on the c column.
moves.29... g5 30. Nf5+: My plan was not to take the h pawn, since it actually helps my opponent (not inmediately, but later).
moves.30... Kd5: Now I can't take h6 or I will suffer from Rh2, but...
moves.31. Rc5+: This makes black lose another time the exchange...
moves.31... Ke6 32. Ng7+: Black resigned. Would I have sac the rook for the bishop? :-). Anyway: overall, a wonderful demostration of the knight's power. Thank you for reading, I hope you enjoyed the game.
